text:
- [Greg] The Amazon End User
Computing team is excited

to add the new Amazon
WorkSpaces Thin Clients
to the portfolio of EUC services.

To that end, this is the
first in a series of videos

that is intended to walk you
through the end-to-end process
of provisioning, configuring,
and then perform the ongoing management
of the Amazon WorkSpaces Thin Client.
I'm Greg LaVigne, team leader

of the worldwide EUC
solutions architect team.
In this first video

of our Amazon WorkSpaces
Thin Client video series,
I'm going to cover a brief background,

hardware specifications,
how to get started,
the regional availability of the service,

Thin Client console prerequisites,
the pricing structure,

how to purchase, and we'll
actually unbox the device

so you know exactly what
your end users can expect.

Also note there will be a
number of links displayed
throughout this video.

I will provide all of
these embedded links here
in the video notes when it's published
so you can access them accordingly.
Amazon WorkSpaces Thin Client
is an affordable end user device

built to work with AWS end
user computing services
that provides users with a secure solution

that gives them instant access
to applications and data
through a familiar desktop experience.

Amazon WorkSpaces Thin
Client seamlessly connects

to Amazon WorkSpaces, Amazon
AppStream 2.0 desktops,
and Amazon WorkSpaces Secure Browser,
formerly known as Amazon WorkSpaces Web.
Amazon WorkSpaces Thin Client
reduces end user computing costs
and simplifies device logistics

by shipping directly from
an Amazon fulfillment center
to end users or company locations.
It also helps improve its security
by preventing users from storing data

or loading applications
on the local device.

It also includes a simple
device management service.

The WorkSpaces Thin
Client provides a console

to centrally monitor,
manage, and maintain devices

and their connectivity to
AWS Virtual Desktop Services.

End users can set up a Thin
Client device in minutes
with little or no IT assistance.

The Amazon WorkSpaces Thin
Client is a compact device

that includes an HDMI out
port to connect to a monitor
and a single USB port to connect to a hub.

Acknowledging it looks similar
to an Amazon Fire TV cube,
this is an altogether different experience
once the device boots up.

The Thin Client is a small
cube that connects directly

to a monitor, keyboard, mouse,
and other USB peripherals,

such as headsets,
microphones, and cameras.
With the optional hub in a bundle,
it can also drive a second monitor.

The bundled hub includes
a both an HDMI out port
and four USB ports.

It can support wired and/or
wireless keyboards and mice
as well as a wired webcam and headset.

So how does this all work?
It requires four easy steps.

First, admins can purchase
the Amazon Thin Client,

along with peripheral devices
like keyboards and mice,
and its USB hub from Amazon Business.

Once purchased, the items
are shipped directly

to the end user, eliminating
any logistical challenges.

Third, once received, end
users can instantly activate

the device using a
one-time activation code.

Finally, the admin can start
managing the registered device

along with associated EUC
services with the AWS console.
Regional availability of the service.

As of June, 2024, the
WorkSpaces Thin Client device

and management service
support is available

in these seven regions, Mumbai,
Canada, Frankfurt, Ireland,
London, Northern Virginia, and Oregon.

For Amazon WorkSpaces Thin
Client administrator console
to work properly,

your system must first
meet specific requirements.

I recommend that prior to
provisioning a Thin Client,

you provision one of the AWS
EUC services listed here.

Again, that's WorkSpaces,
Amazon AppStream 2.0 desktops,
or Amazon WorkSpaces Secure Browser.

Walking through the provisioning
of each of these services
is outside the scope of this video,
however, there are admin guides for each

of these AWS EUC services that
are available online to view.
Thin Client pricing.

You pay upfront for the
WorkSpaces Thin Client device,

plus a monthly service fee
per device to manage, monitor,
and maintain your Thin Client fleet

in the WorkSpaces Thin
Client Management Console.
You begin paying the monthly service fees
for the WorkSpaces Thin Client device
when the end user activates the device,

and you stop paying
the monthly service fee
when the device is deleted from inventory

through the WorkSpaces
Thin Client console.

The WorkSpaces Thin Client
devices are priced at 195,
or 279.99 when you bundle it with the hub

that allows you to
connect a second monitor
and additional USB peripherals.

There's a $6 per month
fee to manage, maintain,

and monitor each device
through the management console.

You also pay for the underlying
EUC virtual desktop service.
Standard pricing for Amazon WorkSpaces,
Amazon WorkSpaces Secure Browser,
and Amazon AppStream 2.0 desktops apply
when these services are used
with the WorkSpaces Thin Client.

WorkSpaces Thin Client
devices are available
for purchase on Amazon Business,
along with the hub in a bundle.

You can ship directly
from Amazon to end users
or to a central receiving location.

Let's walk through a
quick demo of a purchase.
Here, I've opened my browser,
and I'm going to go to amazon.com.

Once in Amazon, I can search
for Amazon Thin Client.
Select it from the smart list,

and you will see the Thin Client
device is the first option,
and here you will see both bundles,
either the Thin Client itself for 195
or the dual screen extension with hub.

Pick which option you
wanna add to the cart,
make a determination on the warranty,
and proceed to check out accordingly.

Now let's walk through
the delivery experience.
The device arrives in an Amazon box

that is about 5.5 inches
tall, 6.5 inches wide,
and nine inches deep.
Looking at the inside of the box

and then pulling the four
components of the bundle out,

you see the device and the
USB hub wrapped in bubble wrap

and the two power adapters
that are boxed individually.

After unboxing and
unwrapping the components,
you can see how the bundle is connected.

The Amazon power adapter plugs
into the Thin Client cube,

while the USB hub plugs into
the USB port of the cube.
Finally, the USB power adapter plugs
into the back of the hub,
as you see here on the right side picture.

It's worth noting that
a keyboard and mouse
are not included in the bundle,

however, you can easily
purchase these via amazon.com
if they are required.

I've highlighted these
additional resources

and will make them available
on the video notes.
The next recommended video
in the Thin Client series is listed here.

My friend and colleague,
Kalon Dillon, will walk you

through the Amazon
WorkSpaces Thin Client setup
and administration experience,

including creating your
first Thin Client environment
in your AWS account,

as well as getting your
first Thin Client activated
and logged into your EUC service.
My thanks for watching,

and I hope this video
provides a baseline for you

to begin your Amazon WorkSpaces
Thin Client provisioning
and ongoing device management journey.
